_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
What are the RMP listed chemicals on site that are above thresholds found in Sec. 68?



Anhydrous Ammonia

Ammonia Solution above 19%

Chlorine



What are the production units on site where each chemical is used?



There are 2 production units that facilitate 3 listed chemicals. They are, the Aqueous Ammonia Production unit where Anhydrous Ammonia and Ammonia Solution > 19% are used (including on-site storage and drumming) and the Bleach Production Plant, where bleach is manufactured from chlorine. 



The Aqueous Ammonia Production Unit produces 29% Ammonium Hydroxide by mixing Anhydrous Ammonia with de-ionized water.  This process also includes storage of ammonium hydroxide in tanker trucks while on-site while awaiting shipment off site or for use in the drumming operation.



In the drumming operation ammonium hydroxide manufactured in ammonia plant is drummed into containers for shipment offsite. 



Bleach is manufactured by mixing chlorine and sodium hydroxide and water in a specialized reactor.  After the bleach is manufactured, it is stored and shipped off-site in bulk quantities and/or is drummed for shipment. This process is used infrequently during the summer months when aqueous bleach availability is low. When aqueous bleach is available, the facility dilutes strong concentrations of bleach onsite for shipment off-site in bulk quantities. 





 Have Process Hazard Analyses been completed and subsequent recommendations developed? 



Borden & Remington has completed comprehensive Process Hazard Analyses for the production units that use listed chemicals above thresholds found in Sec. 68. Piping and instrument diagrams and other safety information were used to consider deviations from design intention. Recommendations were developed and were tracked toward completion.



Have operating procedures been developed/updated for processes utilizing the listed chemicals?



Borden & Remington has developed standard operating procedures (SOPs) for process perf

ormed by its employees. The SOPs for PSM and RMP listed chemicals are reviewed and certified annually.



Have there been any reportable incidents within the last 5 years involving any RMP listed chemicals?



No.



Do employees receive adequate training in the SOPs for RMP regulated chemicals?



All Borden & Remington employees that work within the RMP regulated production units have been certified to posses the required knowledge, skills and abilities to safely carry out their duties and responsibilities. Borden & Remington has in place a training program that ensures that each employee is given refresher training every 3 years.





What Emergency Response Measures are In-Place at the Facility?



Borden & Remington uses chemical sensors and alarms to detect releases from the ammonia or bleach process. The facility has an Emergency Response Plan that conforms to the requirements of 40 CFR 68.95



Does the Company audit compliance with the its RMP? 



Borden & Remington will be improving upon monthly environmental health and safety audits by including a review of components of its Program 3 RMP. The audits include line items that: 

1) Ensure that RMP regulated processes have not changed without proper review and annotation to process safety information 

2) Process Hazard Analyses are updated as new information becomes available 

3) Operating procedures are reviewed annually, preventative maintenance program is on-going 

4) Management of Change Program is being complied with 

5) Incident Investigation protocol is being followed 

6) Employee participation in the RMP continues  

7) Hot Work Program procedures are complied with 

8) Contractor Control Program is on-going  

9) Accepted recommendations are being implemented within the planned timed period.



Does the Company have a standard operating procedure for effectively investigating incidents?



The Environmental Health and Safety Director (EHSD) is responsible for conducting, or appointing a team t

o conduct, comprehensive investigations into the root cause of an incident involving a release of a chemical and or deviation of a production unit in design intent. 



Once the root cause is established, recommendations addressing the root cause are proposed by the investigating team. The EHSD implements accepted recommendations. The investigation criterion remains consistent as the team must complete the Borden & Remington Incident Investigation Form.



Does the Company solicit its employees' ideas relevant to process safety?



The RMP was developed with input from administrative management, operations management and operating personnel. A team of Borden & Remington employees has assessed each regulated production unit. The teams are comprised of employees from every level of the Company's hierarchy. 



Employee input continues to be an invaluable component of Borden & Remington's Risk Management Program and employees are encouraged to bring up safety issues and concerns with Borden and Remington management personnel. 



PHAs were conducted with and are reviewed with personnel responsible for working in areas where covered chemicals are used.



Does Borden & Remington have controls in place to ensure that contractors entering upon the site and or work on RMP regulated production unit are sufficiently trained as to the hazards of the production units?



Borden & Remington restricts access to the regulated production units by unauthorized personnel and contractors. Authorization for access is given only after the hazards and emergency procedures are conveyed to the contractor. The contractor is required to sign an affidavit stipulating their awareness of the hazards and procedures. Production unit egresses are posted with warning signs indicating areas where hazardous chemicals are used and only authorized personnel should enter. Where applicable Borden and Remington may review safety records and safety programs for contractors working in areas of the facility

where RMP chemicals are used.



What steps is Borden & Remington taking to minimize the risk at its facility?   



Borden & Remington installed a new scrubber that replaced the existing scrubber that was installed where the chlorine rail cars are stored at the facility.  The scrubber is only used in emergency situations when and if there were a release of chlorine gas from the railcars.



Additionally in order to reduce the risk of chlorine use Borden & Remington has opted to produce 15% by volume sodium hypochlorite solution by purchasing 19% by volume bleach solution and diluting it to 15% solution.



As an example, in 2017 Borden & Remington converted 17,489,515 pounds of as pure sodium hypochlorite from 19%by volume (15.4% solution by weight) solution diluted to make 15% solution by volume (12.5% solution by weight).  Given the stoichiometry above it takes two atoms of chlorine to make one molecule of sodium hypochlorite.  The molecular weight of chlorine is 35 and the molecular weight of bleach is 77.4. The amount of chlorine required to make 17,489,515 pounds of pure sodium hypochlorite is 15,817,390 pounds.  Similarly it takes two molecules of sodium hydroxide to convert two atoms of chlorine to one molecule of sodium hypochlorite.   The molecular weight of sodium hydroxide is 40 and, it takes two molecules of sodium hydroxide to make one molecule of sodium hypochlorite.  The amount of sodium hydroxide required to make 17,489,515 pounds of pure sodium hypochlorite is 18,086,320.  Therefore by substituting 19% sodium hypochlorite solution diluted to 15% solution for the chlorine and sodium hydroxide reactants  the company reduced its chlorine usage by 15,817,390 pounds as well as reduced it sodium hydroxide usage by 18,086,320 pounds.  



The company still maintains the Bleach Plant and continues to process chlorine albeit at a much lower rate due to supply chain issues that occasionally arise.  The amount of liquid chlorine processed to make sodium hypo

chlorite in 2017 was 3,593,539.  



Borden & Remington has embraced the RMP regulations and integrated it into the culture of the Company. It is this mindset that will result in the continued diligence towards the maintenance and improvement of the Company's Risk Management Program and subsequent lower risk to the environment and the community. As time passes the components of the RMP will become stronger and more effective as they are reviewed and revised. It is Borden & Remington's commitment to facilitating the evolution of an ever-improving RMP that is the catalyst that will result in the significant and permanent reduction of risk.
